message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with signs of pyelonephritis and obstruction due to a stone at the left ureteropelvic junction. The ultrasound shows enlargement of the left kidney with a dilated pelvis and echogenic debris, and the CT scan shows signs of perirenal inflammation. Percutaneous nephrostomy is the most appropriate next step to relieve the obstruction and drain the infected urine. Ureteroscopy and stent placement, and shock wave lithotripsy may be options for treating the stone after the infection has resolved. Intravenous pyelography is not appropriate at this time.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has sepsis and an obstructing stone. Percutaneous nephrostomy is the best option to relieve the obstruction and provide drainage for the infected urine. Ureteroscopy and stent placement may not provide sufficient drainage for the infected urine, and shock wave lithotripsy and intravenous pyelography do not address the urgent need for drainage.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has signs and symptoms of acute pyelonephritis, as evidenced by fever, chills, leukocytosis, and costovertebral angle tenderness. The stone at the left ureteropelvic junction is likely causing the obstruction, leading to the pyelonephritis. Given the size of the stone and the presence of inflammation, the most appropriate next step in management would be percutaneous nephrostomy to drain the obstructed urine and relieve the pressure on the kidney. Ureteroscopy and stent placement or shock wave lithotripsy would be appropriate after the infection is treated and the patient is stable. Intravenous pyelography is not appropriate as it requires the administration of contrast dye, which can further damage the already compromised kidney.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has signs of pyelonephritis and a large stone at the ureteropelvic junction with dilation of the collecting system. Percutaneous nephrostomy is the most appropriate next step in management to relieve the obstruction and drain the kidney. Ureteroscopy and stent placement, and shock wave lithotripsy may be used in less severe cases. Intravenous pyelography is not necessary given the available imaging studies.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has signs of pyelonephritis and a ureteropelvic junction stone causing obstruction. Given his unstable blood pressure and signs of infection, percutaneous nephrostomy is the most appropriate next step for drainage of the infected urine and removal of the stone. Ureteroscopy and shock wave lithotripsy would be indicated once the acute infection is controlled, and intravenous pyelography is not necessary in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and laboratory studies suggest that he has pyelonephritis and urinary obstruction caused by a kidney stone. Percutaneous nephrostomy is the most appropriate next step to relieve the obstruction and drain the infected urine. Ureteroscopy and stent placement may not be adequate to relieve the obstruction caused by a larger stone. Shock wave lithotripsy is not appropriate in the setting of pyelonephritis, and intravenous pyelography is not necessary for the diagnosis or management of this patient’s condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and laboratory findings suggest acute pyelonephritis with an obstructing stone in the left ureteropelvic junction. Percutaneous nephrostomy is the most appropriate next step to relieve the obstruction and drain any pus present in the collecting system. Ureteroscopy, shock wave lithotripsy, and intravenous pyelography may be appropriate later in the management of the patient, but the priority at this time is to treat the infection and relieve the obstruction.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of pyelonephritis and acute obstruction due to the 16-mm stone at the left ureteropelvic junction. Percutaneous nephrostomy is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient to relieve the obstruction and drain the infected urine. Ureteroscopy and stent placement and shock wave lithotripsy can be considered after the acute infection has resolved. Intravenous pyelography is not recommended in this situation as it may worsen the obstruction and delay treatment.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has signs of pyelonephritis, such as fever, chills, and leukocytosis, in addition to urolithiasis. Percutaneous nephrostomy is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient to relieve the obstruction, drain the infected urine and decrease the risk of sepsis. Ureteroscopy and stent placement, shock wave lithotripsy, and intravenous pyelography can be done at a later time when the infection is controlled.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and laboratory results suggest acute pyelonephritis and obstruction due to a ureteral stone. Percutaneous nephrostomy is the most appropriate next step for decompression and drainage of the renal collecting system to relieve the obstruction and facilitate treatment of the infection. Ureteroscopy and stent placement may be considered if percutaneous nephrostomy is not feasible or successful. Shock wave lithotripsy is contraindicated in the presence of infection. Intravenous pyelography is not indicated during acute infection.
